paragraphs.text:
%md
# About
**Objective:** Understand how to build a SPAM Classifier
**File locations:** /user/zeppelin/spamEmail
**Successful outcome:** Classification of spam and ham
**Before you begin:**
**Related lessons:** Classification, SPAM Classifier

---

msg.data:
About

Objective: Understand how to build a SPAM Classifier
File locations: /user/zeppelin/spamEmail
Successful outcome: Classification of spam and ham
Before you begin:
Related lessons: Classification, SPAM Classifier

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Setup
---

msg.data: Setup

paragraphs.title: Retrieve the spam dataset
paragraphs.text:
%sh
rm -R spamEmail*
hdfs dfs -rm -R spamEmail
wget https://s3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/sci-241/spam-dataset/spamEmail.zip
unzip spamEmail.zip > out.log
hdfs dfs -put spamEmail

%md
# Demo
---

msg.data: Demo

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Data engineering

msg.data: Data engineering

paragraphs.title: 1 - Create an RDD for the datafile that contains the email name and the labels
paragraphs.text:
val labelDoc = sc.textFile("spamEmail/SPAM*")
labelDoc.take(1)

msg.data:
labelDoc: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[String] = spamEmail/SPAM* MapPartitionsRDD[63071] at textFile at <console>:27
res3: Array[String] = Array(0 TRAIN_00000.eml)

paragraphs.text:
%md
There are two values, the first is a number (0, or 1) which correspond to wether the email with that title is spam or not spam.  If it’s a 0, it is not spam, if it is 1, it is spam.

The Spark api “wholeTextFiles” will read in all the emails into a PairRdd, where the key is the name of the file and the value is the content of the file.  Do a take on the RDD to get an idea of the structure.  Notice how the key is the entire file path, and in our labelsRdd, we only have the file name.

msg.data:
There are two values, the first is a number (0, or 1) which correspond to wether the email with that title is spam or not spam. If it’s a 0, it is not spam, if it is 1, it is spam.

The Spark api “wholeTextFiles” will read in all the emails into a PairRdd, where the key is the name of the file and the value is the content of the file. Do a take on the RDD to get an idea of the structure. Notice how the key is the entire file path, and in our labelsRdd, we only have the file name.

paragraphs.title: 2 - Create an RDD for the emails
paragraphs.text:
val spamEmail = sc.wholeTextFiles("spamEmail/T*")
spamEmail.take(1)

msg.data:
spamEmail: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[(String, String)] = spamEmail/T* MapPartitionsRDD[63073] at wholeTextFiles at :27 res4: Array[(String, String)] = Array((hdfs://ip-172-31-13-61.eu-central-1.compute.internal:8020/user/zeppelin/spamEmail/TRAIN_00000.eml,"One of a kind Money maker! Try it for free!From nobody Wed Jul 15 14:06:44 2015 Content-Type: text/html; charset="iso-8859-1" Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

CONSANTLY being bombarded by so-called �FREE� money-making systems that teases you with limited information, and when it�s all said and done, blind-sides you by demanding your money/credit card information upfront in some slick way, after-the-fact! Yes, I too was as s...

paragraphs.text:
%md
Because the names in our LabelRdd and spamEmailRdd aren’t the same, we need to massage that data. 
In order to get only the file name, we need to strip off everything before the last “/” in the key field.  
To do so, we’ll use a substring and index function in scala.

msg.data:
Because the names in our LabelRdd and spamEmailRdd aren’t the same, we need to massage that data.
In order to get only the file name, we need to strip off everything before the last “/” in the key field.
To do so, we’ll use a substring and index function in scala.

paragraphs.title: 3 - Clean the files names
paragraphs.text:
val cleanEmailName = spamEmail.map{case (a,b) => ((a.substring(a.lastIndexOf("/")+1)),b)}
cleanEmailName.take(1)

msg.data:
cleanEmailName: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[(String, String)] = MapPartitionsRDD[63074] at map at :27 res5: Array[(String, String)] = Array((TRAIN_00000.eml,"One of a kind Money maker! Try it for free!From nobody Wed Jul 15 14:06:44 2015 Content-Type: text/html; charset="iso-8859-1" Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

CONSANTLY being bombarded by so-called �FREE� money-making systems that teases you with limited information, and when it�s all said and done, blind-sides you by demanding your money/credit card information upfront in some slick way, after-the-fact! Yes, I too was as skeptical about such offers and the Internet in general with all its hype, as you probably are. Fortun...

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now that the spamEmailRDD names line up with the labelDocRdd names, we can do a join.
But before we join, remember the data in the labelDoc is not in the correct format. So we need fix that.

msg.data:
Now that the spamEmailRDD names line up with the labelDocRdd names, we can do a join.
But before we join, remember the data in the labelDoc is not in the correct format. So we need fix that.

paragraphs.title: 4 - Clean the labels
paragraphs.text:
val cleanLabelDoc = labelDoc.map(line => line.split(" ")).map(line => (line(1),line(0)))
cleanLabelDoc.take(1)

msg.data:
cleanLabelDoc: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[(String, String)] = MapPartitionsRDD[63076] at map at <console>:27
res6: Array[(String, String)] = Array((TRAIN_00000.eml,0))

paragraphs.text:
%md
Join the two RDD’s together and only keep the values, since the names of the emails aren’t important to us.  
Also, this part takes a while as some data is moving around the network.  
We want to store a copy of the output data in memory so the rest of this is faster.

msg.data:
Join the two RDD’s together and only keep the values, since the names of the emails aren’t important to us.
Also, this part takes a while as some data is moving around the network.
We want to store a copy of the output data in memory so the rest of this is faster.

paragraphs.title: 5 - Join the RDDs
paragraphs.text:
val labelsAndEmails = cleanLabelDoc.join(cleanEmailName).values
labelsAndEmails.take(1)
labelsAndEmails.cache()
labelsAndEmails.count()

msg.data:
labelsAndEmails: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[(String, String)] = MapPartitionsRDD[63080] at values at <console>:33
res7: Long = 4323

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Data science

msg.data: Data science

paragraphs.title: 6 - Import libraries
paragraphs.text:
import org.apache.spark.mllib.regression.LabeledPoint
import org.apache.spark.mllib.feature.HashingTF
import org.apache.spark.mllib.classification.LogisticRegressionWithSGD

msg.data:
import org.apache.spark.mllib.regression.LabeledPoint
import org.apache.spark.mllib.feature.HashingTF
import org.apache.spark.mllib.classification.LogisticRegressionWithSGD

paragraphs.text:
%md
We now need to convert our words into numbers, using a HashingTF.
This will convert the emails of words into a feature vector of numbers.

msg.data:
We now need to convert our words into numbers, using a HashingTF.
This will convert the emails of words into a feature vector of numbers.

paragraphs.title: 7 - Convert the emails of words into a feature vector of numbers
paragraphs.text:
val HTF = new HashingTF(1000000) 
val emailFeatures = labelsAndEmails.mapValues(feature => HTF.transform(feature.split(" ")))
emailFeatures.take(1)

%md
Now that we have our features built, we need to label the features.  
In addition, this is the last step before we run our machine algorithm, so let's cache the dataset in memory, and take a look at the data.

msg.data:
Now that we have our features built, we need to label the features.
In addition, this is the last step before we run our machine algorithm, so let's cache the dataset in memory, and take a look at the data.

paragraphs.title: 8 - Label the features
paragraphs.text:
val labelsAndFeatures = emailFeatures.map{case (a,b) => LabeledPoint(a.toInt,b)}
labelsAndFeatures.take(1)
labelsAndFeatures.cache()
labelsAndFeatures.count()

msg.data:
labelsAndFeatures: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[org.apache.spark.mllib.regression.LabeledPoint] = MapPartitionsRDD[63082] at map at <console>:41
res9: Long = 4323

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now we have all of our data in the right format, lets build the model.  It may take a couple minutes to build the model

msg.data: Now we have all of our data in the right format, lets build the model. It may take a couple minutes to build the model

paragraphs.title: 9 - Train the model
paragraphs.text: val classified = LogisticRegressionWithSGD.train(labelsAndFeatures,100)

msg.data:
warning: there was one deprecation warning; re-run with -deprecation for details
classified: org.apache.spark.mllib.classification.LogisticRegressionModel = org.apache.spark.mllib.classification.LogisticRegressionModel: intercept = 0.0, numFeatures = 1000000, numClasses = 2, threshold = 0.5

paragraphs.text:
%md
The model is built, we can now start playing with the model and see how it predicts some tests.
If the model predicts 0, it is spam, if the model predicts 1, it is not spam.
Let's test the model with a couple of made up sentences.
Note, this is not the normal way to test models, but a fun and easy way.

msg.data:
The model is built, we can now start playing with the model and see how it predicts some tests.
If the model predicts 0, it is spam, if the model predicts 1, it is not spam.
Let's test the model with a couple of made up sentences.
Note, this is not the normal way to test models, but a fun and easy way.

paragraphs.title: 10 - This is spam
paragraphs.text:
val positiveResult = HTF.transform("Poker for money against real playersGet your favorite Poker action!".split(" "))
classified.predict(positiveResult)

paragraphs.title: 11 - This is ham
paragraphs.text:
val negativeResult = HTF.transform("Please report to principal's office...".split(" "))
classified.predict(negativeResult)

%md
# Result
**You have now:** You have successfully seen how to build a SPAM classifier on Spark.

---

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.

3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
